reporting-org.narrative: Bundesministerium für wirtschaftliche Zusammenarbeit und Entwicklung (BMZ)
Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ)

description.narrative: Das Modulziel besteht in der Verringerung des Strom- und Wasserverbrauchs im Wohnungsbau für Bezieher von mittleren und niedrigen Einkommen und damit in einem Beitrag zum Klima- und Ressourcenschutz und zur Vermeidung von Co2-Emissionen.

Der International Housing Solutions Green Housing Fund II (IHS II) leistet durch die Finanzierung der Erstellung von über 25.700 Wohneinheiten für Bezieher von mittleren und niedrigen Einkommen einen Beitrag zu Verbesserung der angespannten Wohnsituation in Südafrika. Mehr als 5.000 der durch den Fonds finanzierten Häuser, Wohnungen und Studentenwohnheime werden die seit 2011 geltenden südafrikanischen Energieeffizienzstandards für den Wohnungsbau in vielen Bereichen übertreffen und so wesentlich zur Verminderung von Co2-Ausstoß und Ressourcenverbrauch und zur Einsparung von Nebenkosten in den Haushalten beitragen. IHS ist der erste low-cost-housing-Finanzierer in Südafrika mit Fokus auf energieeffizienten Wohnungsbau. Zusammen mit der International Finance Corporation (IFC) hat die KfW sich mit einer Treuhandbeteiligung in der Höhe 15 Mio. EUR (im ZAR-Gegenwert) an der "grünen" Tranche des IHS II Fonds beteiligt, die es dem Fonds aufgrund einer niedrigeren Zielrendite ermöglicht, energieeffiziente Häuser zu bauen und gleichzeitig eine auskömmliche Marge für die weiteren Investoren des Fonds zu generieren. IFC investierte 10 Mio. USD (im ZAR Gegenwert) aus Mitteln der Global Environmental Facility (GEF) in die "grüne" und weitere USD 17,8 Mio. aus Eigenmitteln in die reguläre Tranche. Weitere Investoren in die reguläre Tranche des Fonds sind unter anderem die staatliche Housing Bank National Housing Finance Corporation (NHFC), der Pensionsfond des staatlichen Stromversorgers Eskom, der US-Entwicklungsfinanzierer OPIC und verschiedene private Investoren (PPP-Ansatz). Da der Markt für energieeffiziente Niedrigkostenhäuser in Südafrika bislang erst in der Entstehung ist, ist eine kostengünstige Anschubfinanzierung durch die deutsche FZ sinnvoll. Es ist davon auszugehen, dass vor dem Hintergrund der stark ansteigenden Strompreise in Südafrika, dem allgemein steigenden Umweltbewusstsein und den Klimazielen der südafrikanischen Regierung das Beispiel des Green Housing Fund von IHS starke Demonstrationswirkungen haben und Nachahmer finden wird

IHS II is a privately managed fund with a target size of up to ZAR 3.0 billion, which will invest into the "gap" housing market in South Africa. Depending on the final fund size, more than 25.700 housing units will be financed by IHS II. IHS is an experienced housing investor in South Africa, having already completed more than 11.500 housing units under the predecessor fund South Africa Workforce Housing Fund (SAWHF). ŒWhereas there is a well-designed government housing program for households with a monthly income of below ZAR 3.500 (e.g. BNG), and households with incomes above ZAR 16.000 are relatively well served by both mortgage loans and housing markets, the so called "gap-market" for households in between the two above mentioned income bands is characterized by an estimated shortage of more than 600.000 units. In addition, student housing and other low cost rental housing is also not available in sufficient quantities. Neither commercial banks nor developers are currently adequately addressing the gap-market segment. By providing much needed equity finance to this specific segment IHS is spearheading the inclusion of the private sector into the provision of gap housing units. The 25.700 units planned to be financed by IHS will not only help to reduce the given supply gap but are also expected to have a strong demonstration effect that can entice banks and developers to better serve the gap market. ŒDue to subsidized equity tranches to be provided by KfW and IFC to IHS II, the units financed by IHS II will supersede the South African energy efficiency standards enshrined in the National Building Regulations (SANS 10400 XA), by including specific energy and water saving measures, thereby potentially helping to save up to 33.000 tons of CO2 and 182 million liters of water per annum. The energy efficiency measures will follow best practice examples and will be measured against the normal housing units financed by the predecessor fund as to their social and environmental impacts. ŒKfW plans to invest up to EUR 15 million in ZAR equivalent as a fiduciary holding in the IHS Fund II on the behalf of the BMZ from the German government's budget funds dedicated to the economic cooperation with the Republic of South Africa. The KfW investment as well as the energy efficiency part of IFC's investment will have a lower hurdle return rate than the other investments of the non-energy efficiency investors in order to subsidize the additional cost of the energy efficiency measures. The subsidy element is necessary, as currently the gap housing market would not yet accommodate higher costs of more energy efficient houses. It is however estimated, that the project will result in a strong demonstration effect supporting the desirability of energy efficient low income housing, such that it will also become viable at market rates in the mid-term.

IHS II is a privately managed fund with a target size of up to ZAR 3.0 billion, which will invest into the "gap" housing market in South Africa. Depending on the final fund size, more than 25.700 housing units will be financed by IHS II. IHS is an experienced housing investor in South Africa, having already completed more than 11.500 housing units under the predecessor fund South Africa Workforce Housing Fund (SAWHF). ŒWhereas there is a well-designed government housing program for households with a monthly income of below ZAR 3.500 (e.g. BNG), and households with incomes above ZAR 16.000 are relatively well served by both mortgage loans and housing markets, the so called "gap-market" for households in between the two above mentioned income bands is characterized by an estimated shortage of more than 600.000 units. In addition, student housing and other low cost rental housing is also not available in sufficient quantities. Neither commercial banks nor developers are currently adequately addressing the gap-market segment. By providing much needed equity finance to this specific segment IHS is spearheading the inclusion of the private sector into the provision of gap housing units. The 25.700 units planned to be financed by IHS will not only help to reduce the given supply gap but are also expected to have a strong demonstration effect that can entice banks and developers to better serve the gap market. ŒDue to subsidized equity tranches to be provided by KfW and IFC to IHS II, the units financed by IHS II will supersede the South African energy efficiency standards enshrined in the National Building Regulations (SANS 10400 XA), by including specific energy and water saving measures, thereby potentially helping to save up to 33.000 tons of CO2 and 182 million liters of water per annum. The energy efficiency measures will follow best practice examples and will be measured against the normal housing units financed by the predecessor fund as to their social and environmental impacts. ŒKfW plans to invest up to EUR 15 million in ZAR equivalent as a fiduciary holding in the IHS Fund II on the behalf of the BMZ from the German government's budget funds dedicated to the economic cooperation with the Republic of South Africa. The KfW investment as well as the energy efficiency part of IFC's investment will have a lower hurdle return rate than the other investments of the non-energy efficiency investors in order to subsidize the additional cost of the energy efficiency measures. The subsidy element is necessary, as currently the gap housing market would not yet accommodate higher costs of more energy efficient houses. It is however estimated, that the project will result in a strong demonstration effect supporting the desirability of energy efficient low income housing, such that it will also become viable at market rates in the mid-term.

title.narrative: Für dieses Vorhaben liegt kein Eintrag zur Umwelt- und Sozialverträglichkeit vor.
Für dieses Vorhaben liegt kein Projektbudget-Dokument vor.
No project budget document is available for this project.
Ausschreibungen – zum Zeitpunkt der Veröffentlichung auf der Internetseite einsehbar.
